messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Lasse Koskela" <lasse.koskela@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Timo,
>
> On 2/10/07, Timo Proescholdt <proescho@...> wrote:
> > My question is hence. How am I supposed to bundle my Tests together
> > in general using the 4.0 way of doing things, and how can I do that
> > effectively using Eclipse?
> > Am I running into an eclipse problem or do I just not understand how
> > the new framework is supposed to be used?
>
> I've got an example of creating test suites with JUnit 4 in my blog:
> http://radio.javaranch.com/lasse/2006/07/27/1154024535662.html
>
> Lasse
>

Hello Lasse,
I read your blog and I find this is the a standard way to use JUnit4,
but if you use the eclipse as Timo want, there is a way to do just like
the Junit3.
Here is how to do.
1.your test class must extends junit.framework.TestCase .
so when you use the [new test suite] wizard, eclipse can find
your test class correctly.
2. if your want to use other ide or use the junit3 runner.
You should add a public and static method to your test class.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
return new junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter(yourtestclass.class);
}
--------------------------------------------------------------------
the eclipse 3.2.1 do not need this method more
3. when the eclipse generate the test suite it seems like below.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
public class MyTestSuite {

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("Test for ....");
//$JUnit-BEGIN$
suite.addTest(CalculatorTest.suite());
//$JUnit-END$
return suite;
}
}
------------------------------------------------------------------

Now this is the most important, you should add the RunWith annotation,
and add the value(org.junit.runners.AllTests.class) just like below


import org.junit.runner.RunWith;
@RunWith(org.junit.runners.AllTests.class)
public class MyTestSuite {
......
}
Now you can run the test suite from the eclipse correctly.
I think this method is not good for use the annotation of junit4.
But it would ok for using the eclipse. Maybe this is what you want
"an alternative enabling the building of a test suite dynamically".
^_^

I test it only use the eclipse junit4 runner, I do not run ant for this.
